instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: 820-000165 red light no fan spin, no waterdamage
threads.message:
Dear, 

I try to read from other Threads, but I see to get stuck.

<CAPACITOR>C7582</CAPACITOR> was short. Removed and replaced. After that laptop worked fine. But after 10 seconds the same Talanoium Capacitor was short again. 

Now I removed <CAPACITOR>C7582</CAPACITOR> and there is no fan spin no boot. 

The light charger is red without batterij.

I read from other threads

<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> 
Pin 19 Diode mode = 0.456V (red probe on pin 19)
Pin 19 Diode mode = 2.3V (black probe on pin 19)
Pin 20 Diode mode = 0.456V (red probe on pin 19)
Pin 20 Diode mode = 2.3V (black probe on pin 19)

<CHIP>U5110</CHIP>
1 = 3.4v <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
2 = 0v
3 = 3.5v
4 = 2.2v

8 = 3.3v
7 = 3.4v
6 = 3.4v
5 = 3.4v

Any help would be appreciate

threads.title: 820-000165 red light no fan spin, no waterdamage
threads.message:
"I read from other threads
------------
Pin 19 Diode mode = 0.456V (red probe on pin 19)"
Where did you read to measure diode mode with black probe on ground???
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]
BTW, stop to write the end "V" when you post diode mode readings.

"after 10 seconds the same Talanoium Capacitor was short again"
Did you really check no short to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> after removing <CAPACITOR>C7582</CAPACITOR>?
Why did you suspect the new capacitor, to remove it?
Didn't use one with similar nominal voltage???

threads.title: 820-000165 red light no fan spin, no waterdamage
threads.message:
Thanks for reply Amigo:
There is no short to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> I have a steady 8.59v
<CAPACITOR>C7582</CAPACITOR> was shorted, I know how to find shorts with my DC power supply. Just to stupid for diode mode. Hope to learn from you.
<CAPACITOR>C7582</CAPACITOR> was burning on my FLIR camera on 4amps 1v. I removed and the short was gone. System booted. Just not so long.


I replaced <CAPACITOR>C7582</CAPACITOR> from a donar board.

Where my readings oke from <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>?

threads.title: 820-000165 red light no fan spin, no waterdamage
threads.message:
<CHIP>U5110</CHIP> looks good.

You've said to read threads here; where did you see ANY mention to inject voltage into <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> BEFORE checking for high-side MOSFETs???
Don't you really like to work more carrefully, putin logic in your job?

"I know how to find shorts with my DC power supply"
Doesn't look like...
You was very lucky to get same cap shorted, not a CPU MOSFET; do NOT force your luck!
A simple ohm check shows you if is safe to inject voltage; do not tell 1V didn't risk anything.

Do you get now <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>/S5?

threads.title: 820-000165 red light no fan spin, no waterdamage
threads.message:
Angry teachers is most likely to learn fast.

Keep screaming. I learn twices as fast. 

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.3
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 0.001

Sorry, i Guess it was not so smart to inject AMPS.

threads.title: 820-000165 red light no fan spin, no waterdamage
threads.message:
You didn't inject amps, but voltage.
You cannot control voltage and current at such time!
Ohm law is very clear...

You have missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> probably.
Are you using original Magsafe 2 charger?
Post <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, PM_BATLOW__L, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> and all PCH's RTC signals.

threads.title: 820-000165 red light no fan spin, no waterdamage
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> = 3,4
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> = 1,0
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 1,0

the rest i need to see what is all that.

threads.title: 820-000165 red light no fan spin, no waterdamage
threads.message:
"the rest i need to see what is all that"
Didn't read all the above mentioned link?

"<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> = 1,0
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 1,0"
Both bad.
Check <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: 820-000165 red light no fan spin, no waterdamage
threads.message:
Studing very fast. 

Angry teacher  is the best!

Why do many MacBook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> show red light without a battery attached?

threads.title: 820-000165 red light no fan spin, no waterdamage
threads.message: ALL Magsafe 2 machines have the same behavior...

threads.title: 820-000165 red light no fan spin, no waterdamage
threads.message:
It just randomly went on after going deeper.

Is it possible to leave  <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  out? Or would it make the system very unstable?


With BAT only it won't turn on.

On <TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR> with battery only connected
Pin 5 = 7.8
Pin 1,2,3 = 0
Pin 4 = 0

On <TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR> with battery and Charger connected
Pin 5 = 7.8
Pin 1,2,3 = 8.4
Pin 4 = 8.2

threads.title: 820-000165 red light no fan spin, no waterdamage
threads.message:
It is booting and working.

Just not charging or booting without battery.

threads.title: 820-000165 red light no fan spin, no waterdamage
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR> is bad, change it.
Guess what internal diode does there...

threads.title: 820-000165 red light no fan spin, no waterdamage
threads.message:
It should protect the board from getting to many current in? Lets say when a wrong battery is attached?

I don't get how the same <TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR> works both ways, for charging and for suppling current when DCIN is disconnected.

Oke, all working now!

threads.title: 820-000165 red light no fan spin, no waterdamage
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR> lets the current to flow directly from battery to MLB, when no charger present.
It didn't that in your case...

threads.title: 820-000165 red light no fan spin, no waterdamage
threads.message:
thanks for your answer.

TO/FROM BATTERY it says. 

So how this Diode also charge the battery? Looks like one-way only right?

threads.title: 820-000165 red light no fan spin, no waterdamage
threads.message:
"current to flow directly from battery to MLB"
This is EXACTLY what its internal diode does; no matters if MOSFET is open, or not.
To charge the battery (MLB to battery), the MOSFET must be turned on.
